Award.AwardTitle: Investigations of the Common-Envelope Phase of Binary Star Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
A wide variety of exciting astrophysical phenomena involve a pair of stars orbiting each other, often exchanging or sharing material and sometimes merging to form a single object. Regardless of their initial or final state, these systems pass through a phase in which both objects orbit within the same "common envelope", through which they exchange and share material. Complex computer simulations of this phenomenon are perhaps the only way to account for all of the factors that determine the ultimate fate of such a system. The PI and his collaborators will carry out such simulations, which are made possible by the development of terascale and petascale computing technology and investments by NSF in high-performance computing infrastructure. They will use software developed as part of this project to enhance undergraduate astronomy education by creating interactive binary star simulation modules for an online Digital Demo Room site and for a new course in computational astrophysics. Students will be involved both in the research and in developing education materials.

The team will carry out computer simulations to study the physics of common envelopes, a short-lived but crucial phase in the life of close binary stars that may lead to a wide variety of astrophysical phenomena, including certain types of supernovae, gamma-ray bursts, and mergers between stars or black holes. This phase is inherently three-dimensional and cannot be studied using the one-dimensional simulations that underlie our understanding of single-star evolution. They will focus on understanding the sources of energy a common-envelope binary can draw upon in ejecting the outer atmosphere of the larger star and on predicting the appearance of the phase in cases in which the two stars merge together.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Over half of all "stars" in the sky are actually binary or multiple star systems. A non-negligible fraction of binaries start their lives separated by a small enough distance that, when the more massive of the pair finishes hydrogen fusion in its core and becomes a red giant, it engulfs the less massive star. As the cores of the two stars orbit within this "common envelope," they experience drag due to the envelope gas and spiral toward one another. This process releases gravitational energy that is used to eject the envelope. Some of these systems halt their inspiral at a significantly reduced separation, while others continue until they merge. The common envelope phase is a critical ingredient of theories for how many different kinds of astrophysical phenomena arise, including cataclysmic variables, X-ray binaries, Type Ia supernovae, luminous red novae, and gravitational wave events.

We have created computer simulations of common envelope evolution to explore different aspects of this process. In one set of simulations, we have studied the effect of the release of latent heat when hydrogen and helium ions recombine with free electrons to form neutral atoms as the envelope expands. This latent heat can help the binary eject more gas than it would otherwise. In another set of simulations, we have studied whether binaries containing supergiant stars and massive black holes can inspiral enough that the black hole binaries they leave behind can merge due to emission of gravitational waves. Both sets of simulations required us to create new software; for the supergiant case, our simulations were the first in the field to include radiation transport.

We also carried out calculations for related purposes. In one set, we showed that common envelopes and supernova explosions in binary systems can produce gravitational waves via previously unrecognized mechanisms. In another, we used the outputs of common envelope simulations to show that, when a low-mass star in a binary ends its life by casting off all of its remaining envelope as a planetary nebula, the material ejected during a previous common envelope phase can shape the nebula in a variety of different ways. A third set of calculations explored the circumstances under which binaries of different masses and evolutionary states would undergo the unstable transfer of material that leads to common envelope evolution.

Broader Impacts

As part of this project, we trained a graduate student and five undergraduate students to conduct research and present their work at scientific meetings. We gave public talks to share our work with the community at large, and we co-authored a textbook on common envelope evolution to train students and researchers in the subject. We significantly upgraded a public-facing website, the Illinois Astrophysical Dynamics Demos, to enable visitors to learn about astrophysical simulations and how they are used in a variety of different subfields.
